title: 107_s1266
content: The "SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001" aims to increase the income eligibility level for the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP) to 300 percent of the Federal poverty line, potentially providing coverage to 1.4 million uninsured children. The "SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001" allows states to expand income eligibility under SCHIP. The "SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001" allows states to expand income eligibility for low-income children under the Social Security Act by substituting '300 percent' for '200 percent'. The "SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001" allows states to expand income eligibility for low-income children under the Social Security Act by substituting '300 percent' for '200 percent'. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to child health assistance provided on or after October 1, 2001. The "SCHIP Enhancement Act of 2001" allows states to expand income eligibility for low-income children under the Social Security Act by substituting '300 percent' for '200 percent'. Additionally, states that opt to expand income eligibility may receive additional allotments under Title XXI of the Social Security Act. States meeting certain requirements by December 31 can be eligible for additional allotments under Title XXI of the Social Security Act, with income standards for children set at 250% and 300% of the poverty line. States meeting specific criteria by December 31 may qualify for additional allotments under Title XXI of the Social Security Act, with income standards for children at 250% and 300% of the poverty line. For states intending to use the additional allotment for premium assistance for family coverage under an employer-sponsored group health plan, they must submit a description of expected planning and implementation costs to the Secretary. The Secretary shall allot an amount to each State with an approved State child health plan under Title XXI of the Social Security Act, based on specific criteria and income standards for children. States may qualify for additional allotments by December 31, with requirements for using the funds for premium assistance for family coverage under an employer-sponsored group health plan. The Secretary shall allot funds to States with approved child health plans under Title XXI based on specific criteria and income standards. States may qualify for additional allotments by meeting certain requirements. The Secretary allots funds to States based on criteria and income standards. Allotments under paragraph (2) are determined similarly to paragraph (1). States receive allotments in addition to the 250 percent allotments. Funds allotted to a State remain available for expenditure for three years, with unused allotments returned. The Secretary allots funds to States based on criteria and income standards. Allotments under paragraph (2) are determined similarly to paragraph (1). Unused funds are returned to the Treasury if State requirements are not met. Additional allotments can be used for child health assistance or a premium assistance program. The additional funds allotted to States can be used for a premium assistance program for family coverage under an employer-sponsored group health plan. The program must be cost-effective and ensure children receive minimum benefits and cost-sharing protections. The State can use additional funds to implement a premium assistance program for family coverage under an employer-sponsored group health plan. Employees eligible for employer-sponsored health coverage can apply for full premium contribution from the employer. The State evaluates the impact of the program on access to health coverage. $1,000,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal years 2002 through 2011 for this purpose. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will evaluate premium assistance programs funded by the Social Security Act to identify implementation issues and assess if the assistance is replacing existing health insurance coverage for children. A report with recommendations for legislation will be submitted to Congress by January 1, 2006.
